description:
Great place for sharing plates between a group, although it does tend to get a bit loud in the space.

The heirloom tomato panzanella was my favorite dish of the night - would absolutely recommend. The chicken fried anchovies were perfectly crunchy on the outside, not so fishy, and super flavorful. Our waiter recommended the broiled yellowtail collar and while this was a bit tricky to share, the salsa that it came with was crazy delicious and paired well with the fatty fish. The main we ordered was the roasted halibut. I didn't think the fish was that special, but the succotash it was served on was one of the best things we ate.

Super attentive and accommodating service. Lots of other interesting things on the menu so would definitely come back and try more items!
author: Joanna X.

description:
We were a party of four so I knew we could order a lot and get a taste of the menu.

We started with Tuna & Uni Tostadas with charred avocado was delicious, Deviled Eggs, Wagyu Steak Tartare satisfied with each one.

We enjoyed our mains entrees:
-Grilled Duroc pork chop with bacon, Brussels sprouts and pecan mole with just enough sweetness to enhance the meat.
-Five-spice lamb shank was generous portion of fall of the bone lamb, lots of fat so I didn't end up eating a lot of the meat but was delicious.

-Marin Sun Farms Burger thickly slathered with bacon-onion marmalade, white cheddar, charred scallion aioli and a strong dose of horseradish was also stood out.

Didn't get to try their dessert because we headed across the street to Humphry Slocombe to get ice cream.  The ambiance was great, the food was good just a simple place to go good for groups and couples. Definitely a good choice for a worthy dining experience. 4 stars!
author: Maria M.

description:
My takeaways from my experience here:
1. There is no need to deal with crazy waits or impossible reservations for good quality food.
2. I'm getting old because regardless of where I go- it's always too loud. Our table of 7 had a hard time hearing each other.
3. If you want to go out afterwards- this place isn't in the most happening location in the Mission- but it's great if you're looking for a chill night.
4. I hate tapas or small plates. Really- I hate sharing my food.
5. Getting wine bottles for big groups is more economical. Glad they didn't have cocktails- we would have each gotten our own $15 cocktail if they had.
author: Julianna I.

description:
What an understated restaurant in the heart of the Mission. 

We ordered... 
-Bacon-Kimchi Deviled Eggs
Yup. Sounds a little offsetting but trust me, it's a must try! 

-Roasted Bone Marrow
Tons of rich hearty flavors with this plate. I liked the combo of the garlic confit with the acidity of the tomatillo and celery heart. 

-Heirloom Tomato Panzanella
Probably my favorite dish of the night. The heirloom tomatoes were just PERFECT with the ricotta cheese.

-Grilled Hangar Steak Frites
The one outlier :~( The steak was "erratically salty" as my friend says. Nonetheless, the fries were great - albeit very Burger-King-esque.
author: Caroline K.

description: Solid. But nothing stood out to me. We had the deviled eggs, uni chip, hamachi crudo, chicken liver toast, and I had the seafood stew for the main. Others had the steak and said it was ok. A bit gamey.
author: Laura D.

description:
Delicious food! A wonderful neighborhood restaurant with outdoor seating (though the outdoor seating has limited lighting and no heating-- so try to come early if you want to enjoy) that allows you to dine with your pup if you so choose. 

They mostly have small plates and bites, with some larger plates if you feel in the mood for entrees. I was fine with sharing a couple small plates between my partner and myself and that was more than enough for the both of us. Delightful and delicious with attentive service! They have a poached chicken meal that is reminiscent of hainan chicken rice, and they forgot to add a sprinkling of peanuts on top, and the wait staff noted that, and ran immediately back to the kitchen to correct the error. It was something that I wouldn't have noticed (it wasn't listed on the menu) if they hadn't found out, but it shows that they are well-trained and have fine attention to detail. That was something that really spoke out to us, and they were also really kind and receptive to us bringing our dog, and even brought water out for him. 

The chicken fried anchovies are delicious! Get them as a bite-- though they are perfect enough to share for 2. The tuna and uni tostadas are smaller in size, but each order comes with 2, and I'd recommend getting them. The roasted bone marrow is definitely hearty -- coming with TWO bone marrows instead of one. The achiote cured hamachi was also a favourite of ours; something that we will most likely order again. 

I'd love to come back for brunch or dinner again, as the wait staff was attentive, the dishes were scrumptious, and the atmosphere was beautiful.
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
We got a variety of things: bone marrow, fried mushrooms, chicken appetizer, burger.  For desert we had mini pies.

The bone marrow stood out, it was really good.  Everything else was good.

This place is a bit expensive, but i like it and will probably go back.
author: Michael E.

description: We made reservation for 4 people and had a nice afternoon there. We order chorizo and egg chilaquilles. The size is huge. Tasty and nice ambience and cozy place. Friendly serving, too.
author: Rijanti H.

description:
3.5 stars. We got a whole bunch of small bites to share between the three of us. 

MUST GET:
Tuna and uni Tostada - perfectly flavored. Like the red pepper slices on the tostada and super crispy and thin tostada on the bottom. 

Complementary bread - excellent. Taste like bread from tartine. 

SOLID:
Octopus with potatoes - like the octopus but didn't care for the potatoes (in potato salad form)

Steak tartare - needed a bit more seasoning and more on the chewy side. A bit too close to the butcher form of steak tartare. 

Roasted mushroom with pecorino - this dish is a bit blend / blend but the mushroom was of great quality. 

SKIP:
Hamachi crudo - hamachi is fishy, though hamachi is sizable for this dish

Chicken liver mousse - the mousse is very salty for certain bites.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but I just felt disappointed each time a dish was set down in front of me and the portion of the main listed ingredient was so small, there was not enough to savor.  The portion of main ingredient is really the size of a condiment.

We are not afraid to spend a few hundred on a meal, either.  It's just that when we do we want to feel like we were given enough food to enjoy tasting it.

The "bites" are the size of an amuse bouche.  The small plates are the size of a small appetizer.  The main dishes are the size of a small plate.

If I was eating the creations of a total genius chef that might be ok.  But this food just wasn't at that level.  And part of the reason the food wasn't so thrilling is because the portion of main ingredient is so small that the flavor isn't featured.  This leaves each dish unsatisfying to the palate, let alone the appetite.

FYI we were here for dinner on a weeknight.

We had Uni tostadas, summer squash salad, haddock and a burger. The size of the burger was large enough. Nothing else!
author: katie s.

description:
The octopus appetizer was really delicious. I was only disappointed in the small bits of meat in the dish itself - not enough meat. It would be better if it were made greek style with the whole tentacle broiled.

I also enjoyed the yellowtail collar which was very oily and moist. That was a thumbs up. 

I had a big lunch that day so I just opted for the steak tartare (appetizer) as my entrée. The meat was flavored well and had a side of chips. If you prefer bread, you will need to order it on the side. I found that the chips and the tartare together were too salty for me, but spreading it on the bread worked out fine.

The wait staff here is very attentive and they all get a thumbs up.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I realized I have been here 4 times in the last 2 months so this is overdue. Service is welcoming, beers are cold, food is right on point. 
What I like especially is that it has a perfect mix of menu items for an adventurous foodie as well as probably one of the better Burgers this city has to offer. Go, visit!
author: Sam S.

description:
Great little spot in the mission. Easter brunch was wonderful and while the place had a short brunch menu, we found something for everyone. 

Enjoyed the kimchi & bacon deviled eggs and also the roasted hen of the woods mushrooms. Both would have benefitted from a bit of salt.

Scramble was really good, but also lacked a bit of seasoning and the onion got super flaccid making consistency a bit weird with the hard asparagus. Fried chicken sandwich was a hit as was the quiche. Also perfect bacon. 

Great service, good vibe. Would like to try their fuller menu.
author: Bob K.

description:
I was in fact writing back to a work colleague in DC earlier today about my weekend - the long four day weekend is sending us spinning as we are used to working extremely long hours without any breaks. Our social life becomes work life and vise versa. He was asking me how my weekend was as he was getting stir crazy, and I said, "Long and getting a bit boring.  But I did have one nice outing with my divorced girlfriend at a newish restaurant in an old stumping ground of mine." 

On a rather chilly but sunny Sunday my girlfriend and I came here for brunch. 

I had my heart set on uni so I ordered the uni tostada. he dish was petite and one bite size. Very good but on the pricey side. The kimchi deviled egg was interesting but slightly lonely sitting on a plate. I consumed both.

The fried chicken sandwich with the abundant fries seemed to be the best on the menu. I did the veggies egg scramble which was also quite good - more French than you think. 

The restaurant did not seem to have a wait which to me means a winner. I don't like waiting in line or getting asked to leave. Brunch should be leisure activity, it's a perfect time waster and if all possible, it should go on and on for the rest of the afternoon.

The brunch menu is rather limited but does have the basics.  Drinks are innovative but coffee was what hit the spot for me. Dessert came with a lone candle - they remembered it was my girlfriend's birthday. 

Food was rather good. Line non existent. All pluses. Parking was lucky. No issues.  Neighborhood, as they say, in transition.

A perfectly hassle free Sunday brunch spot.
author: Victoria E.

description:
A very nice neighborhood restaurant.  I visited here for dinner when my friend came into SF for the weekend.   Out party shared the octopus and the yellowtail collar small dishes.   

I wish the octopus dish had more pieces of octopus. The octopus pieces were cooked tender and the entire dish was flavored well. I did find the bed of ground chickpeas to be on the saltier side.  The yellowtail collar was also cooked and seasoned good. The fish meat was moist and tomatillo sauce was a good accompaniment. 

My main was the bone on pork chop. This is a heavy dish, due to the bean and bacon mole.   I found it to be a bit oily, which lead to the heaviness of the dish. But the flavor was delicious.  The pork meat was  cooked well, but the meat was still juicy.  A very good hearty dish.

The service of our server and the staff was great.  I would come back here again to try the other small dishes.
author: Marck N.

description:
Pretty casual place. Tons of parking. However, I felt the neighborhood/area was kind of sketchy. 

If you're a party of two, the seating arrangements are pretty close to the neighbors next to you. 

I highly recommend to order as many small plates as possible and share. 

Highlights of dinner were: 

1) Tuna and uni tostada - my favorite dish of the night! 

2) Roasted bone marrow - Dish comes with cloves of garlic that tasted absolutely divine. The toast that this dish came with was super duper hard/crunchy. I only ate one because I was afraid the next one would break my teeth.  

3) Brussel sprouts panzanela - So good! With a blend of pistachios, sourdough bread and goat cheese. 

4) Grilled pork chop- Very generous sized pork chop and jam packed with flavor! 

Dinner was perfect and service was two thumbs up.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
Had a great experience here at Son's Addition which opened about 2 months ago. I really liked the interior and the service was great! I'll definitely come back here again. 

Things I ordered:
- Bacon-Kimchi Deviled Eggs
- Tuna & Uni Tostada 
- Brussels Sprouts Panzanela
- Achiote Cured Hamachi 
- Grilled Spanish Octopus
- Pan Roasted Black Cod
author: Jenn L.

description:
Wait - Reservation @ 13:00 Sunday

Value - $13/dish

Dish Size: Medium/Small

Tuna and Uni Tostada - There's no better way to describe this dish than it tastes like "California." It's amazingly fresh with a touch of sourness from the pickles, served on a light but crunchy tostada. 

Bacon and Kim-Chi Deviled Eggs - A solid and decadent deviled egg. My only critique is that there isn't much of a kim-chi flavor. 

Fried Chicken Sandwich - By far one of my favorite fried chicken sandwiches in SF. The chicken is cooked perfectly and the breading is light yet extremely crunchy. I'm not a huge fan of the sourness from the slaw but it does make the overall dish taste fresh and light. I prefer Alta MSP's sauce/slaw which is a buttermilk flavor. 


Son's Addition is now on my list of "go-to" brunch places. Everything on the menu sounds appetizing and the dishes we ordered tasted amazing. There is an evident core set of flavors throughout the dishes: tanginess, freshness, and lightness; which gives the meal a cohesive feeling. 

If you're a fan of Marlowe than you'll love Son's Addition. There are quite of few similarities between Marlowe and Son's Addition but what sets Son's Addition apart is the more relaxed atmosphere and the fusion oriented cuisine. Son's Addition, much like Marlowe, is a small trendy space with seating packed to the brim. The difference with the interior of Son's Addition is the industrial/NYC look is toned back, in favor of a more minimal and brighter color pallet, making the space feel roomier and brighter. 

I am huge fan of Son's Addition and wouldn't hesitate to go back. There are definitely many more dishes on the menu that I can't wait to try. If you're left with the choice between Marlowe or Son's Addition, I would say you can't go wrong with either choice. It's a win-win.
author: Julian L.

description:
We had a large group brunch here on a recent Saturday. Parking in this part of the Mission is not great, especially when there is a festival going on, like Carnival on this particular day. The inside is simple, clean, and cozy. It's not a large restaurant so reservations might be a good idea.

I was only able to try a few dishes as I was under a dietary restriction, however my other half had lukewarm comments over the large spread of dishes our group shared family style. He enjoyed the Marin Sun Farms Burger but especially did not like the Fried Chicken Sandwich, which he said was mostly fried batter. My main dish was the Seasonal Scramble(asparagus, spring onions) which was a bit bland for my taste. I doused it with hot sauce. 

Service was attentive and quick. Overall, I look forward to trying more of their menu when I'm not constrained at this cute little spot in the Mission. There is a parking garage not too far away, if you're struggling to find street parking.
author: Angela L.

description: The kind of restaurant you long for in this city. Humble staff, family friendly vibe, high quality food and drink. Tuna uni tostadas, you can eat a half dozen easy. Yellowtail collar. Get it. Lamb shank is the best deal in the city. Show up, have a great glass of wine, or four, and order a lot of food. EVERYTHING is great.
author: Tony S.

description:
A group of friends and I had dinner at Son's Addition Friday night. Highly recommend you make a reservation since it's a smaller restaurant and definitely busy. The space is welcoming and hip with a small bar and open kitchen. I thought everything on the menu was very reasonably priced.

Drinks: 
The wine menu is extensive and descriptive so you'll definitely find something that will spark your interest. The menu is categorized by flavor profiles, so it's super easy for you find what you're looking for! We went through 2 bottles of the Pieropan Soave 2015. Crisp, refreshing and a perfect pair with both our lighter and savory dishes. 

Food:

Deviled eggs: definitely start with this. Not a strong kimchi taste, but is smoky from the bacon and a little garlicky from the other ingredients. 

Hamachi: pass. It was good but I definitely think there were better things on the menu. 

Grilled Spanish Octopus: Super interesting flavor! The curry yucca was an interesting pair with the octopus. This was a favorite dish.

Beef tartare: Just enough seasoning to add flavor but still let the quality of the beef shine through. 

Burger: Perfectly juicy and medium rare! The bacon onion marmalade added the perfect savory and sweet bite. Served with fries and pickles- it's a steal at only $15

Fried chicken: The special of the night. We ordered 2 plates of it because it was so good!!! So juicy and crispy.

Pork Chop: Meh. It was cooked well but lacked flavor. Reading it's description we expected something a little bolder.

Lamb Shank: GET IT! My personal favorite dish of the night. A SUPER rich and flavorful dish. The goat cheese polenta was creamy and the perfect pair with the unbelievably tender lamb. If you like bold flavors, you will not be disappointed.

Dark Chocolate & sea salt cookies: Just when we thought things couldn't get better.....we had these. Rich, sweet, and just a little salty. If you're a fan of ooey gooey cookies you're gonna love these.

Service: 
So nice and thoughtful. We got help from several different people in the restaurant and everyone was so kind. The 5 star service moment of the night was when our server Charles noticed we were unsatisfied with our pork chop and came back with the bill letting us know he had taken it off. So nice of him!
author: Courtney N.

description:
The brunch crew finally got together last week for our somewhat monthly ritual. I've been meaning to try Son's Addition, so I made a reservation about 1.5 weeks prior for Saturday, May 26th at 12:30pm. They only take reservations for up to parties of six on OpenTable, so I had to call and change the headcount when we became a party of nine.

*Tuna & Uni Tostada: with charred avocado, pickled red onion, radish, cilantro, hazelnut dukkah and miso-black garlic sauce ($12) x6, extra Tostadas? (+$36)
*Roasted Hen of the Woods Mushrooms: with pecorino, balsamic gastrique ($9)
*Crushed Avocado Toast: with arugula, fennel, lemon, olive oil, chili flakes and leek green togarashi ($10)
*Fried Egg Sandwich: with black garlic aioli, bacon, jack cheese and charred avocado on seeded bread ($15)
*Fried Chicken Sandwich: with cilantro slaw, mole aioli and cotija cheese ($15)
*Spring Quiche: with english peas, wild mushrooms, bloomsdale spinach, leeks, and goat cheese ($14)
*Buttermilk Biscuits and Chorizo Gravy: with avocado, cilantro and cojita cheese ($15)
*Spicy Corned Beef Hash: with breakfast potatoes, braised kale, fresno chiles and poached egg ($14)
*Seasonal Scramble: with asparagus, sunchokes, roasted spring onions, manchego and green garlic ($14) x2
*Marin Sun Farms Burger: with white cheddar, bacon-onion marmalade and charred scallion aioli served with fries and house dills ($16)
*Malted Waffle: with whipped satsuma butter ($13)
*Muscato Sabayon: with mixed berry compote and brown butter streusel ($9)
*Pineapple Cake: with whipped creme fraiche ($9)
*Indiana Jones: not your average michelada ($9) x2
*NV Bodegas Cruzat Brut, Pinot Noir / Chardonnay, Lujan de Cuyo, Mendoza, Argentina ($36) x4, Bellini (+$4)
*Cappuccino ($5)
*Drip Coffee ($4) x3
*Orange Juice ($5)

I saw uni and immediately wanted the tostadas. They were good, but I wish they had more uni. They was only a tiny bit on top, so hard to taste. And after going over our bill for this review, I realized we were charge $12 per order instead of the $11 listed on the menu. Also, for each round (we did two rounds of tostadas), we ended up with a surcharge. The first one was $12 and the second was $24. Not sure if that was to add the appropriate amount for the number of people at the table, but it ended up being $108 for I think 15 tostadas. A little pricey for what you get if you ask me. Moving on to the other food...

I liked the fried chicken sandwich. Though I do have a weakness for any fried chicken sandwich. The chicken was nice and crispy and the slaw added a nice contrast. I also enjoyed the biscuits and gravy as it kinda reminded me of indian curry. It had a similar profile. And I find indian curry very comforting. The rest of the food, I just found okay. A lot of people were surprised about how much they liked the waffle as it looked so plain. I think it may have been the orange butter that elevated it a bit. For the cake, there was an orange almond cake listed for $8, but I think we ended up getting a pineapple cake instead? I took a small bite, so I don't remember it much.

Our waitress was sweet. We had a big party, so she managed to serve us well. Especially since we like to drink. They have mimosas and bellinis on the menu, but we just decided to order bottles instead. She was sweet enough to give us the berry mix so we could make our own as I'm more of a bubbly purist. The indiana jones is a must if you like micheladas. They had a nice subtle spicy kick. Speaking of spice, if you like heat, make sure to ask for their two hot sauces. Definitely a good way to kick it up a notch on the savory dishes.

Fun brunch, but I wasn't really impressed with the food. Work checking out once though.
author: Elena N.

description:
I was quite surprised by this humble establishment. Tucked away in the Mission district, this restaurant is comparable in quality to places like Progress or State Bird Provisions.  Walking in, I felt the local vibe as it wasn't overly crowded, but considering it was right after work, most people were grabbing a drink and a quick meal .

The Bacon kimchi egg  were simple, yet an explosion of flavor. Eggy, crispy bacon, low tones from the sesame oil, and a surprising spiciness at the end 
 
The uni tostadas may have had some of the best avocados I've had.  So fresh and bright with Avocado flavor. The pickled vegetables and garlic sauce were just enough to compliment and not overwhelm. The tuna and uni were probably the least pronounced in the flavor. Although it's better that the fish flavor not be overwhelming, it didn't seem as pronounced as I would like. The chip that held everything was just the right amount of crunch. That may have been the textbook definition of what I would want from a mini tostada chip. The only problem is they give you two small chips. I was quite sad once I consumed them 
 
The bone marrow was executed well. Not a soup and not a struggle scooping the marrow. A wonderfully rich beef flavor, with the right amount of garlic confit. The celery hearts were a little distracting, but they did give it some freshness and texture. The bread was super crispy, and initially tasted weird, but it blends well with everything after a second.  

The octopus was a solid choice, but they don't serve it as good as New York. it had a tender enough texture without being per se chewy, but some chew is there. It wasn't as crispy as I like, but it still has some crisp. I loved the playful use of yellow curry. It wasn't too spicy, but the curry flavor was definitely there.
author: Gill S.

description:
I googled "Son's Addiction" to look at the menu before coming to the restaurant and all these rehab centers kept popping up. 

I mean, my alcohol consumption isn't THAT bad. 

But apparently, my eyesight is! I should've typed addition without a letter "C".

Judging by the 5 star reviews for this brand new restaurant with former Marlowe chef creds, I was excited to dine here. I love when owners brave through the high SF rents and struggles of soft openings. The place is casual, yet manages to be cozy and chic. Perfect for a relaxing date night or catch up with friends and their kids in tow. 

The wine selection is littered with gems and are appropriately priced for the neighborhood. I ordered a cabernet franc, but decided to give it to my friend and got a cava instead. It was crisp and easy to drink, also shocking that the $9/glass price is very friendly. 

We shared a few small plates to get an idea of the menu: pork chicharron with spicy fermented salsa (wish the chicharron was crispier, definitely liked that it was not super spicy), brussels sprouts panzanella with sourdough, beets, pistachio and goat cheese (great variation of the Italian classic), poached chicken and crispy skin (wish there was more skin instead of rice) achiote cured hamachi (fresh fish with a bite!), grilled octopus (fantastic) and roasted bone marrow. As I took in every bite, there were definitely some dishes that I liked and some just ok. The roasted bone marrow was a HUGE disappointment, as there was hardly any marrow on the bones. I was literally scraping the cross-section hoping to pick up something more ... but no dice. Eating the marrow made me long for better versions of it in SF: Lolinda and Wayfare Tavern come to mind.

We appreciated the service as there were several folks coming by our table to refill waters, take away plates and deliver food. This is a very welcoming neighborhood restaurant. 

However, the excitement just wasn't there for me. And as we walked out of Son's Addition, I couldn't help but wonder, with all those 5 stars on yelp, "Did we all go to the same restaurant?"
author: Janice C.

description: Been here multiple times and it is always a delight. Special shout out to Anthony for great service. And the owners are great people, Nick and Anna.
author: John D.

description:
My coworkers and I don't always agree on restaurants. And, I sure as hell don't agree with my boss' choices of restaurants. His favorite SF restaurant is the now defunct Sinbad's. If the "view" is what you're after, you're better off eating crumbs from the ground of the Ferry Building. But, shhhhh don't tell him.

My co-worker and I were talking about new restaurants and we both excited about the opening of Son's Addition, from a Marlowe chef alum. But, after her visit, she told me to not go.

Psssh, of course I wasn't going to listen as I'm the type of person that has to try it for myself.

First things, first...do come with reservations during the weekend. This is one of the hottest new restaurants in SF and it was crowded on a Friday night. Second, parking can be tough so allot an extra 15-20 minutes to look for parking. Better yet, take a Lyft. Bart is also three blocks away.

The Seasonal California Menu with global influences is broken into small bites, small plates, large plates, and desserts. Wine & beer only.

For SF standards, the prices are very reasonable with the most expensive entrée being $25. My friend and I ordered 2 bites, 3 small plates, 1 entrée, and 2 glasses of wine, and it was less than $70 pp including tip. 

As for the food, it seems like we went to a different restaurant than all the Yelpers here. Sadly, there was only one standout dish and the other five were underwhelming. Some of the dishes seemed overly complicated. Clearly, I'm in the minority here so we probably went on an off night.

*Tuna & Uni Tostada w/ charred avocado, pickled red onion, radish, cilantro, hazelnut dukkah, miso-black garlic sauce ($11): http://bit.ly/2A8MRzH
Favorite dish of the night, the tuna + uni were fresh and the bite had great layers of texture.

*Pork Chicharron w/ spicy fermented salsa ($9): http://bit.ly/2AWcof6.
You can never go wrong with crunchy pork rinds but the pork belly was really salty. The fermented salsa wasn't spicy and didn't add anything to the dish.
 
*Beef Tartare w/ black garlic, lime, herb salad, yukon gold potato chips ($11): http://bit.ly/2zQgnWw
As someone else mentioned, it's missing something. Perhaps mustard for some flavor? The chips weren't the best vessel as they easily broke from the weight of the tartare.
 
*Chicken Liver Toast Points w/ persimmon mustard, sea salt ($10): http://bit.ly/2jhNLzs
Least favorite dish. The chicken liver was missing that rich, complex flavor and bread was wet on the ends from the mustard seeds.

*Roasted Bone Marrow w/ tomatillo, sea salt, garlic confit, celery heart ($15): http://bit.ly/2iruLgN
We were really sad about this dish - there was barely enough marrow (from both of the bones) for one of the toast points. My co-worker had the same issue when she visited the week before. 

*Five Spiced Braised Lamb Shank w/ goat cheese polenta, root greens, shiso gremolata ($25): http://bit.ly/2knlfjd
Cooked well - fork tender shank and creamy polenta...but too many strong, competing flavors and the shank itself was very salty. Five spice powder, goat cheese, [bitter] root greens, and shiso leaves all have pretty aggressive flavors alone IMO. When combined on a plate, it was very overwhelming.

Service was very kind and earnest. This is truly a neighborhood restaurant as the staff is warm and pretty attentive despite it being busy. I've been trying to get rid of a hacking cough and our server was nice enough to have the kitchen boil some hot water for me to drink. We had early dinner reservations so pacing of dishes was on point.
 
Formerly a Salvadoran hole-in-the-wall, the owners have done a great job transforming the space into something bright and modern with some rustic touches. Not much sound dampening as it was pretty loud and hard to maintain a conversation. If you want a more quiet meal, it's probably best to come for an early weeknight dinner.

Overall, I was hoping to have a 5 star experience like everyone else but like many new restaurants, Son's Addition is probably still finding their groove in the kitchen. Once they get their outdoor seating in place, I plan to revisit in a couple of months. By then, I hope to give a better update.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Dinner review. American.

Tuna uni tostada - 3 - Can't taste any uni
Bone marrow - 3
Chicken liver toast - 3
Beef tartare - 4
Lamb shank - 3

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description:
We went on a busy Saturday night. 

Kimchi & Bacon Deviled Eggs-
Kinda weird that they are so small and dainty. It should be $2.50 for one egg, not $2.50 for half. Mine tasted okay but again, they were really small. My GF said hers was greasy, she mentioned how it was greasy 3 times during the dinner which was weird since mine was not. 

Charred Octopus-
My GF and I agreed that they should charge $6 less and remove the octopus from the dish. It is dark in the restaurant so I am unsure there was even any octopus in the dish, but the potatoes and sauce were great. 

Chicken mousse toast-
This was the best dish we had, all the flavors worked well.

Halibut-
The halibut was our main entree and it was not good. The halibut was overcooked and it was served on a bed of corn and vegetables, 100% sure these were the vegetables:
https://www.birdseye.com/product/mixed-vegetables-4/

Table-
The table was broken, instead of moving us from the broken table to the one next to us they tried to fix it for about 5 mins. They left the table so it was not level but they said it was better than leaving it bouncing around.

Wine-
They were out of Chardonnay, which was odd. When we were able to ask for two more glasses of wine, we asked for a blanca and got a Riesling. It was really loud and the tables are placed close together so that might explain the error. 

Overall, we wouldn't go back.
author: Josh H.

description: We were a large party and Monica and the rest of the staff gave us great attention and care. We loved the chicken liver mousse toasts, the seafood tostadas were just perfect. The hen of the woods were meaty and satisfying. I recommend ordering them with the hangar steak. The vegetables under the steak were too salty as well as the deviled eggs (I called them little salt bombs). I did mention to the chef. The halibut was very lovely and light. The Shishito peppers were just right,nicely charred.  They offer a $20 corkage. We ordered scariest of desserts but I didn't try them ass I was too full. Loved this place, would happily return
author: Tammy N.

description:
It was just alright...

The place is cute and got busy quick. If you're on a date, you'll need to lean over the food to hear him/her. I could keep track of both my neighbor's conversations. The service was just ok as well. Everyone was nice, but sometimes it was hard to get our waiter's attention. The food was so meh. The deviled eggs seemed more interesting than it tasted. The chicken liver toasts were pretty good. The arugula salad had a spice/flavor in there that was overbearing. The Brussels Sprouts were pretty good. The cod was the best part. Overall, the food was mediocre.
author: Caitlyn S.

description: I used to live in SF and I was back for a quick visit. The food was great! Fresh and clean flavors, you can tell they are passionate about what they do. There's a really cool vibe, and a really attentive staff. I went for brunch and had the chilaquiles and was super impressed! Now that I live in San Diego, that's a tough dish to compete with, but they nailed it! Next time I'm in town, I'm looking forward to dinner there. I only wish this place was open when I lived there...it would've been my go-to spot for sure!
author: Mary G.

description:
I just had an incredible meal here. Monica and Anthony were awesome. The kitchen also having a good time. I love a place where it at least seems like the staff are happy to be there. 

The deviled eggs were delicious. What a bite

The tostadas just work! A couple bites of amazing.

But the chicken and rice made my day. Little bit of heat and chicken fat? Thats the best kind of food.

I'll be back.
author: BRADY K.

description:
It's been awhile since I've dined at a hot new restaurant in SF! I have to thank my gal pal who is more attuned to the hot spots since I don't seem to be in the 'know' of the cool hip places. 
Anyway, it was her birthday celebration, so we came to Son's Addition to celebrate, and by golly, did we have a wonderful birthday feast!!

As I mentioned in my quick tip, definitely make reservations. The bar area is quite small and towards the back of the restaurant. The kitchen is semi-open, so you can see the chefs working hard to prepare the amazing dishes with such precision and care. The space is quite nice and simplistic, and they utilize every ounce of it. We sat in the middle section of the restaurant surrounded by other 2 top tables. Don't be surprised if you're sitting right next to another party. I'd request the corner tables in the front if you want to have more space and feel less crammed. 

The menu is split into 3 sections, from Bites and Raw; Small Plates; and Large Plates. Since we practically ordered everything on the menu, here are my must orders:

1) Pork Chicharron - I'm filipina, so of course, I'm going to order this. Serving is a bit smaller than anticipated, so might want to order a few so you don't fight over who gets the last piece. Crispy and savory chicha goodness! You won't be disappointed. The spicy fermented salsa wasn't that spicy, and that's to my liking since I'm not a spicy fan.

2) Tuna and Uni Tostada - You taste more than tuna over the uni, and this is bite sized so it fits in the palm of your hand. Best to get two orders of these, especially if you are a party of 4. 

3) Brussels Sprouts Panzanela - This was one of my favorites, as I love my brussels. Good savory flavor with the baby beets, goat cheese and pistachios. The sourdough croutons are the best part. The flavor combination is so on point! Bursting with amazing flavor and goodness!

4) Chicken and Crispy Skin- with Coconut Rice. I was expecting more of the crispy skin, but it was crisp to perfection and the chicken is quite tender and juicy. 

5) Pork Chop - Tender and juicy goodness. This is served with butternut squash, bacon brussels sprout ragu... as if I couldn't get enough of the yummy brussels! 

6) Black Cod - This was another favorite of mine. The fish was so delicate and melt in your mouth. Great flavor, too as it's served with celery root, delicata squash, leek, kimchi romensco. 

7) For dessert  - get the dark chocolate and sea salt cookies and the Moscato Sabayon- poached french butter pear and brown butter streussel. The pear (seasonal) is perfectly poached and paired with the brown butter streussel. Oh mylanta! It's not too sweet, nor too heavy. The perfect happy sweet ending to an amazing meal.  

Great selection of wines by the glass and bottle. I had a lovely Rose since I wanted something light and fruity. Nice service with friendly, attentive staff! Prices are reasonable, and you're paying for quality and amazing food!

You've got a winner in the Mission! Congrats Son's Addition! You guys have hit a home run!

Cheers my dears!
author: Gill C.

description:
Cute and tasty new restaurant in the mission! Came here with some girlfriends and we got to try a number of things to share that were overall tasty and interesting. This menu reminded me of many favorites from park tavern and Marlowe with a twist. 

Faves
- bone marrow
- Deviled eggs
- octopus- very interesting curry dish
- black cod- romesco sauce was amazing
author: Daniela J.

description: What a cute place! I came here on a weekend for brunch and although we made a reservation, it didn't seem too crowded. The kimchi deviled eggs were delicious, but i wish we got more for the price. It only came with a single egg. I ordered the breakfast sandwich which was good as well, but nothing special. I would come here again if I were looking for a solid brunch.
author: Amanda F.

description:
I was in town for the weekend and was eager to check out a new restaurant in this culinary wonderland. I was very happy with the owners' ability to accommodate last minute reservations. And I was thoroughly impressed with the dishes coming out of the kitchen. 

Started off with a couple of bites:
-Bacon-kimchi deviled eggs with green onion and black sesame seed
-Tuna & uni tostada with charred avocado, picked red onion, radish, cilantro, hazelnut dukkah, and miso- black garlic sauce

Both were light and refreshing and really whet the appetite

For small plates tried:
-Poached chicken and crispy skin with coconut rice with fermented soybean salsa
-Chicken liver mousse toasts with persimmon mustard, sea salt and lavender honey 

Hands down the chicken and rice was my favorite of the evening- love coconut rice. Chicken liver mousse toasts were a pleasant balance of flavors

For large plates, tried:
-Heritage pork chop with butternut squash, bacon-brussels sprout ragu, pecan mole
-Pan roasted black cod with celery root, delicata squash, leek, kimchi romesco
-Marin Sun Farms burger with white cheddar, bacon-onion marmalade, Romaine lettuce, tomato confit, and charred scallion aioli served with fries and house dills

Each plate was succulent and unique and all flavorful- just depends what you're in the mood for - pork if you want hearty, fish if you want light, or burger if you're looking for comfort. I enjoyed them all! You can't go wrong because the quality and execution are on-point and really raise the bar on these types of dishes. 

Unfortunately I didn't try the desserts which were limited and not calling to me. Nonetheless it was such a treat to be here and even though I have preferences, I was thoroughly satisfied with the entire meal and experience. The team here definitely knows what it's doing and is doing it right and impressively!
author: Rose I.

description:
Ambiance-warm, cozy and rustic. Seems perfect for girls' night or date night

Service-friendly and prompt, no complaints here

Drinks-fiddlehead cellars rose was nice. 
Their cocktails are premade and not to order, but still enjoyable

Food-
Uni tostada-one order only comes with 2 servings. Couldn't taste any uni, which was disappointing since I love uni. Basically tasted like a super expensive chip with guacamole and other fixings 

Brussels sprouts panzanella-not particularly unique but I really enjoyed this. Beets and brussels sprouts paired nicely with the creaminess of goat cheese and the croutons were deliciously crunchy.

Achiote cured hamachi-this tasted fresh and tropical but that's all I remember 

Chicken Liver Mousse toasts-hard pass. Toast was too charred, liver was too salty and the mustard was overpowering. Marlowe does this better.

Beef tartare-tasty with potato chips

Grilled Spanish Octopus-octopus was tender. Loved the flavor of the yucca curry but there was so much curry compared to octopus.

Five Spiced Lamb Shank-lamb was fall off the bone tender but the dish was a little too salty and heavy for me.

Pan Roasted Black Cod-Cod melted in your mouth, I'd recommend this entree!

Overall, more a 3.5 stars. Really enjoyed the neighborhood feel and ambience and food was close, but didn't quite hit the mark.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Maybe it's because this place just opened, but the service we received here was almost impeccable. 

Our table wasn't ready for 20 minutes after our reservation, so we were a bit cramped waiting towards the back in the bar area. Once we finally got our table, I only got to eat a few appetizers since I didn't order an entree, but I was impressed with what I got to taste. 

- Bacon-kimchi deviled eggs: Mmm... Creamy and tasty, not entirely overwhelmed by either the bacon or kimchi flavors. It was satisfying having the contrasting crunch of the bacon as well. 
- Roasted bone marrow: Couldn't get enough of this one. Bone marrow is always about the seasoning and texture, and they didn't certainly didn't skimp.

I'll certainly be back for a full dinner after they hammer out their reservation issues -- hopefully next time we won't have to wait as long for a reserved table.
author: Christine L.

description: This was my second time to Son's Addition and it was just as good as the first. The space is charming and simple but the food is what really shines here. The bone marrow was melt-in-your-mouth amazing (my mouth is salivating as I write this). My friend is a pescatarian so we did mostly veggies and fish. The heirloom tomatoes were amazing and the hamachi was one of my favorite side dishes. And last but not least...dessert, which I usually never order. They have a chocolate chip cookie with sea salt as one of the desserts - sounds boring but is f-ing amazing. One of the best cookies I've ever had and I bought several to take-away. All of the wine we drank was reasonably priced and they serve beers from local brewers. All in all this place is solid and a wonderful addition to the neighborhood.
author: Kyle M.

description:
This place was a fantastic find. Came here for the Refugee Food Festival but ended up ordering some of the Son's Additions plates as well. Service was amazing and the waitresses are very friendly. The decor is lovely with a nice black and white sophisticated vibe. 

We ordered the Charred Spanish Octopus and it was fantastic. Probably the best octopus I've ever eaten. The octopus itself was perfectly tender and beautifully marinated with a lime aioli that helped to brighten up the dish. The octopus was also paired with soft potatoes, which grounded the flavors, and snow peas that added some fresh greens. A wonderful balance of flavors and textures worth savoring!

Would definitely recommend splurging a little on the food here! Great vibes for a summer evening.
author: Sarah T.

description: My husband and I have been DYING to try this place! Let me tell you, it did NOT disappoint! It's in a great location and the ambiance is relaxed and clean! We never had to wait for our water refills (we were thirsty) and our server had our delicious wine out in under a minute! I'd have to say the pork chop was my favorite thing we tried, coto perfection! I already have a reservation there next week, can't wait to try more things!
author: Molly H.

description:
Absolutely stellar experience. Came for Saturday brunch and had the uni/tartar app, liver pate, deviled eggs, fried chicken sandwich, and a house made parfait. All dishes were exquisite!

BUT, equally as important, the service was an 10/10. Staff were super knowledgeable, extremely accommodating, and just friendly as can be. 

Cant wait to come back again soon!
author: Sam L.

description: This is one of the best new restaurants to open in the Mission in quite some time. It achieves that oh-so-elusive mix of being both a neighborhood restaurant and offering delicious, interesting food. Their dinner is great and their brunch has become one of our go-to choices. You can make a reservation (!) and everything on the menu is great.
author: Kira M.

description:
We went here for brunch and was not impressed. The service was so so, we had to flag someone to take the order. Then we waited for food. And most of it was cold by the time it hit our table. Also, my deviled egg look so lonely on the relatively big plate. The deviled egg and the fries were generously salted and the mushrooms lacked flavor. 

They did try to make up with complementary dessert but they were out of the cookies. My husband said we'll get whatever the pregnant lady wants and they brought sabayon - raw eggs and moscato... cause they were out of everything else. 

Not impressed.
author: Wildeflower M.

description:
Come with a group so you can order as many small plates as possible. 

Our meal was satisfying but didn't blow anyone out of the water.. Here's what we ordered:
-Kimchi deviled eggs
-Roasted bone marrow
-Grilled Spanish octopus
-Poached chicken and crispy skin (our favorite)
-Beef tartare
-Burgers
author: Kim I.

description:
Great food with good service in a somewhat noisy setting with bad lighting. Would go again.

By the numbers:
Food 5/5
Ambiance 4/5
Service 5/5
Value 5/5

Deviled eggs: Eggsellent
Hamachi crudo: Excellent
Heirloom tomato panzanella: Excellent
Roasted hen of the woods mushrooms: OK
Poached chicken with crispy skin: Excellent

Ambiance: I give them credit for having sound panels on the ceiling, but it was still quite loud. Magic hour provides great lighting throughout, but when the lights came on, the different color temperatures clash badly, and the kitchen bleeds into the dining room. Tough problem to fix and most probably won't notice, but seated next to the counter, it detracted from an otherwise great experience.
author: Navi O.

description: Great neighborhood restaurant with a warm and welcoming vibe. I love the location, and its perfect for entertaining out of town guests or for a first date.  Wine selection is great, and server's recommendations were on point. Nothing but friendly service and great food. Recommend the bone marrow and the octopus. Highly recommend!!
author: hanni c.

description:
I was very excited to try this new restaurant finally. We came here for an early dinner on a Friday night and it was pretty quiet at the time. The service was warm and attentive.

We started with the chicharron. This dish should not be on the bites section; it's probably more appropriate as an appetizer. The dish consists of thick slices of pork belly, cooked to perfection (nice crispy texture on the outside) and fried pork rinds on top. Unfortunately the pork rinds were not as crispy; they were a little stale. Overall it was a good dish. We also tried the kimchi deviled eggs and the tuna-uni tostada. Both were excellent dishes and very tasty. The tostada was super tiny thou! 

For the main course, we tried the pork chop and the lamb shank. The lamb shank was cooked nicely and come with a goat cheese polenta and braised greens. The sauce that came with it was awesome. Everything was well-seasoned. I had a bite of the pork chop and it was cooked beautifully and very tasty as well. 

In terms of price point, I think it's a really good value. They also have lots of wine selection around $40. I will be coming back!
author: Sam M.

description:
Come on people. Do you just grow money on tree? Tiny portions. Mediocre food. Prices are off the chart. If you want to spend money go to the Ritz or any 5 star hotels in town and get a decent brunch for the same price, pound by pound. 

One small waffle cut in four for $14. What??? No fruit on top either. 

Two pieces of tuna the size of a dime for $10. Huh???

It is an insult to be charged this much for this type of food. 

Not me!!!!
author: N T.

description: Service was great, food was delicious and the ambiance is comfortable but upscale. Server recommendations were on point, and they accompanied my friend who asked for bread for the table, even though that wasn't on the menu and not usually offered.
author: Carla C.

description: This is my favorite new gem in the neighborhood and it seems largely undiscovered. We got burgers, panzanella salad, and warm cookies--all super delicious and reasonably priced. Hoping enough people will discover it so that they stick around, but not so many that it becomes hard to get in!!
author: Adrienne S.

description: The ambiance is fun and modern, with cool artwork and nice, open bar and kitchen concept. Our server was very friendly, but we especially liked Anna who came by whenever we couldn't get ahold of our server. Good selection of wines and beautifully decorated plates. The three stars is because it seemed that the pork was a bit dry and the overall dishes a bit salty.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Hm...what's the best way to put this. I liked the food, but wouldn't come back? Service was good and I was happy with the food, but nothing was impressive. 

Bacon Kimchi Deviled eggs-bacon is good with everything, but the kimchi was too sour for me with the egg

Tuna and Uni Tostada-this is actually really small and you can't really taste the uni. 

Roasted bone marrow-this was a big portion and so good. Love the celery with it. Never had that with bone marrow before. 

Cured Hamachi-it was fresh

Beef tartar-it was a good mixture and gave enough chips

Black cod-cooked perfectly and seasoned well

Brussels sprouts panzanela-a good salad

-Grilled octopus-thumbs up

Dessert was soft chewy chocolate chip cookies.
author: Karen H.

description:
We ordered 5 bites/small plates between 2 of us and the portion was just right. Pretty stuffed so we've gotta come back for dessert soon. Everything we ordered was great! 

Broiled yellowtail collar - fresh and tender with a tangy sauce that brings out the taste of the fish really well.

Poached chicken with crispy chicken skin - reminded us very much of Thai chicken rice (Khao mun gai) as well as Singapore's Hainanese chicken rice but served with a twist.  

Roasted bone marrow with garlic confit - melts in your mouth! 

Chicken fried anchovies - fried goodness with yummy aioli dip.   

We'll be back!
author: Yizhi A.

description:
A cockroach crawled up my foot. How do I know? Felt something move on my ankle and looked down to see a smallish 1'' brown cockroach on me. 

Was traumatized the entire cab ride home. 

Ok onto the food: 
Kimchi bacon deviled eggs: I loved this but my friend didn't. I think the flavors really went well together. A tad salty but hey so am I. 

Grilled octopus: the curry flavor went well with the octopus which was cooked nicely, not rubbery. 

Poached chicken coconut rice: it's really spicy! I love coconut though. They fried the skin until it was like a chip. 

Cod: I usually don't like fish but this one was super melt in your mouth fish. 

Also knocking off a star because the temperature in the restaurant fluctuates constantly from freezing to warm. Ladies next to me kept putting on their coats. I was just cold the entire time. Doesn't help that the air vents are angled onto my face. Maybe get some automated temperature control? 

Give the food a shot but bring a warm blanket and keep your feet up.
author: Momo M.

description: Overpriced and overrated. Went for a large group dinner and was underwhelmed by the service and food quality. Bone marrow and the chocolate chip cookies are the best things on the menu, but I'm sure you could find better and cheaper versions of these two menu items elsewhere in SF. Everything else we sampled was bland or overdressed. The portions were also offensively petite given the price. They were out of two wines I attempted to order. Do not expect the servers to pour you wine or even offer you a glass from which you can drink the table wine.  The gent who poured the water was the most attentive of all the staff who worked there. This place had a lot of hype and was such a letdown.
author: Julia K.

description:
*** In Short ***

Dessert definitely steals the show here.

*** In Depth ***

So let's put this out there first, but Son's Addition has no relation to Sons & Daughters, lest we besmirch the name of that lofty establishment (okay I've never actually been yet, so I don't really have an opinion here LOL).

And with that out of the way... the food here is really just okay, with nothing really standing out among the the deviled eggs, bone marrow, and black cod we ordered, but nothing was terrible either.

What DID stand out, however, was their dark chocolate cookie dessert, which was AMAZING. So, come here for that. Who needs real food anyway?

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - There's a mix of high-top counter seating and regular table seating, so accessibility shouldn't be an issue.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description: Creative menu, and short but precise winelist. Service was awesome. Great vibe on a Saturday night - nice music and buzzyz
author: Polina M.

description:
My husband & I had brunch here this past weekend & I cannot day enough good things!! Trendy modern atmosphere super close to BART. Their dishes well balanced, & their service was great!
We were outside looking at the menu & the hostess let us come in a few minutes before they opened because they were ready to serve- so nice! We came with our baby in a stroller & they were super cool with it & accommodating. 
We had:
deviled eggs- quite tasty. I did want a little more kimchi flavor but still would order it again.
Waffles- FLIPPIN' FANTASTIC! Please order this!! Very unique flavor & the butter flavor as out of this world & I usually skip the butter. One bite was under cooked (a little dough-y) :/
Hen of the woods mushrooms-
Tuna uni toast- very small portion but excellent! I don't usually like uni but I really enjoyed this bite. My husband who loved uni was wished there was more uni flavor. We both thought it was well balanced.
Small appropriate portions.
We can't wait to go back for dinner!
author: Ashley G.

description:
The best deviled eggs I've ever had. In my life. Who adds kimchi to their deviled eggs?! Son's Addition, that's who. And then they top it off with two tiny slices of very crispy bacon, sitting right on the egg yolk. Pure delicious genius. This was the best dish of the night. 

Rest of the dishes:
- Tuna uni tostada - Husband said it was delicious.
- Chicken liver toast - I'm not into pate, and this was pretty good.
- Chicken fried quail - Really good. The skin was crisp, and the bird was well seasoned. It was a little difficult to eat because it was so small, but we used our hands and just went for it.
- Bone marrow - This was pretty disappointing. It was served with roasted garlic that we were instructed to spread on the crostini before putting the bone marrow on top. Don't do it! Also, the bone marrow had celery leaves on it. Scrape that off! Everything took away from the bone marrow flavor. We tried it the recommended way, which just ended up tasting like garlic and celery on a crostini. For the second crostini, I left everything off and just spread the bone marrow on it, which was much better. But there wasn't enough bone marrow to cover two crostinis per person. 

Lastly, the cocktails leave something to be desired. I assume they didn't have a liquor license. The bubbly was good though!
author: Jaching H.

description:
Outstanding experience here last week! Everything we tried was either epic or good, not a single disappointment. 

We started with the bacon kimchi deviled eggs and they were phenomenal, hopefully they will be on the menu for quite a while! Next was a tuna ahi tostada which was also pretty amazing, just an amazing combination of flavors and texture in a single bite.

Then it was onwards and upwards with their roasted bone marrow, almost impeccable in preparation. Our next small plate, the beef tartare was missing something, and just a squeeze of lime did the trick, and this was probably the only "just good" item on the menu.  We finished our meal by sharing the heritage pork chop and it was sumptuous, zero complaints.

Really divine meal, and all the items paired well with some glasses of their Malbec.  Our waiter was really knowledgeable and attentive without ever being overbearing, really friendly vibe.

We got there on the early side and by the time we left, the dining room was full.  So check it out soon before it gets too popular!
author: Saminda W.

description: What a fabulous brunch spot & a great addition to 24th Street!! The ambiance is lovely & bright, the servers and staff are super friendly! We were taking a break from our vigorous exercise and decided to stop in for bubbly and brunch. The menu is amazing and I cannot wait to go back! Most dishes between $10-15 for brunch, which is average for SF. My mom had the corned beef hash and it was literally the best I've ever had! Spicy and delish!!! The braised kale was a lovely touch too. They were very accommodating of her request for scrambled eggs over poached. I had the fried chicken sandwich which was excellent but I think missing a little something - pickles or spice or something. The fries were also really delicious!! Just perfectly cooked, salted and not greasy. I will def be back for the avocado toast and to try the dinner menu!
author: Kylie F.

description: Awesome place! Best French fries in the Bay Area - I speak after investigating for 18 years in the Bay Area. We absolutely loved the quality of food, the welcoming atmosphere (very friendly chef and staff) and the style! Can't wait to try more as well as their amazing preserves!
author: Raph G.

description:
Came here with reservations for a party of 6 for dinner. We all enjoyed the meal and almost all the dishes that we ate family-style.

- Tuna & Uni Tostadas: Delicious and perfect bite size as a starter for everyone.
- Beef Tartare: I wished the portion was bigger than the number of chips on the dish because the beef tartare was delicious with a citrus kick.
- Brussels Sprouts Panzanela: there were sourdough bits along with brussel sprouts which were good until I tasted the goat cheese (which I'm not a fan of). For those who like goat cheese, this would be a good order, but because I tasted it in every bite, I didn't eat more than one scoop. However, the bread bits with the brussels is a good combo.
- Achiote Cured Hamachi: flavored with pineapple-coconut water, peanuts, and spicy chile on top. I couldn't handle that spicy, so I ate everything around it and it was light and delicious.
- Roasted Bone Marrow: garlic was all over this, and I sure do like my garlic. This was super flavorful and I would reorder this in a heartbeat. Smearing the garlic over the small toast and then topping it with the bone marrow was a party in my mouth. 
- Poached Chicken and Crispy Skin: mmm another good dish to reorder! The crispy skin was a perfect texture and flavor paired with the chicken coconut rice. I love coconut rice so I definitely was a fan.
- Chicken Liver Mousse Toasts: Another great dish. Chicken liver has been a part of my life growing up eating banh mi with it so I was looking forward to this dish when we ordered it. The flavor was delicious with the touch of persimmon mustard and the toast was a good pairing with it. Highly suggest ordering if you're a fan of liver mousse.
- Pan-fried Black Cod: Very unique with a kimchee flavor, but the fish was good well with lots of flavors. Good option for fish lovers.
- Five Spice Braised Lamb Shank: I am not a fan of lamb so I didn't indulge, but my friends were fans of the tender, soft meat. There was also goat cheese polenta below it which made me not want to try even more.
- Marin Sun Farms Burger: Delicious & has fries but by the time this dish arrived, I was too full. Though I did pick at the yummy fries :)
- Muscato Sabayon: This dessert had a pear with brown butter streusel and it was delicious. Desserts were on point. 
- Orange-Almond Cake: Almond cake? Yum! With small sweet orange pieces on top. Delicious!

Overall, great food with great people. Service was ok, since we had to ask a few times to get the check. We all left full and satisfied.
author: Amanda C.

description:
wanna dineout for cash n see who SON'S who?
i proly brek lunch dinnas foody nzas who blog
suckas posts is odd
can stand an ADDITION hangry mission
tapas busting green onion
u dancing like krump i eat tartare lump

TFL;DFR service is friendly but give em time foodwise. booths are narrow & killer stiff for your back.

(^_^) Bacon Kimchi Deviled Egg $2.5 (http://bit.ly/2lkM87i)
el sabor mejor glad i saved for last

(^_^) Uni Tostada $10 (http://bit.ly/2i9rzGn)
like uni taco not just for tuesdays

(-_-) Beef Tartare $10 (http://bit.ly/2ySmMRm)
chunk size more like poke than tartare
liked chip thickness but kinda like they'd been sitting out

(-_v) Chicken Liver Mousse Toasts $9 (http://bit.ly/2iG6KG8)
wish toasts had been crisp

*don't sit on the booth side* if you can avoid it - these muhfuhs are stiff & narrow. #thatswhatshesaid

otherwise quaint wood / white / kitchen curlies open air atmos. fun nextgen dyson airblade in the baffroom.

friendly workers. aussie / nz accent waitress cool. hostbro w the star trek colors outfit live long n hipster. jk
author: Dan B.

description:
Great food, awesome service.

I read on EaterSF that this place was opening this week, and I happened to be in the area. According to the article, the chef used to be the head chef at Marlowe. I'd been to Marlowe and loved it, so I wanted to give this place a try.

Son's Addition is located in the Mission, near the original Philz location. Street parking only, but I'd say it wasn't too hard to find parking. The interior is lit pretty dim, with candlelight at each table. Blue and white patterned tiles adorn the bar areas. Good for a date, and also saw some families with children. 

Good wine collection, and there's also a small bar seating area (I'd say enough to fit about 5-6 people). I ended up ordering a Pinot from Sonoma, my own way of supporting wineries that may have been affected by the Sonoma/Napa fires. Also plenty of foreign wine to choose from.

For food, got a bunch of small bites to begin:
- (1) Bacon-Kimchi Deviled eggs: crispy bacon and spicy/garlic-y flavor of kimchi complements the smooth deviled eggs very well.
- (2) Roasted Bone Marrow: they recommended smooshing the roasted garlic onto the crispy bread,  and then spreading the bone marrow on top. It was good, and even more refreshing than the bone marrow dish I had at Marlowe.
- (3) Spicy Beef Tartare: not that spicy, but flavorful overall. Came with radish yukon potato chips, which  went perfectly with the tiny cubed tartare bites. I'm not that big on tartare in general, but this was good.
- (4) Little Gem Lettuce: I have not had chicories and goat cheese together in a salad before, and they went really good together. I think it also had sunflower seed or pine nuts (couldn't tell which) which were also good -- but if you're allergic to nuts, make sure you ask. 

To finish off, we shared the following:
- (5) Marin Sun Farms Burger: came with fries and house dill (wasn't too salty) that were good. Burger itsef was a little heavy for my taste, but still good. We got it medium rare, and it was perfect.

Throughout our entire meal, the staff made sure to make us feel well taken care of. Rarely had an empty glass of water for longer than a few minutes, but at the same time didn't rush us to order more or get out faster than we wanted to. 

All in all, food was great. Couldn't try dessert because we were full to the brim, but would love to return sometime and order perhaps one less small dish so we can fit in a dessert dish! The whole check came out to something like $73 before tip, and I'd say it is worth every dime. Looking forward to going back!
author: Soo Jung R.

description: The services at this restaurant is excellent. every one is very friendly, they came to added our water and check if we needed help. The appetizers are a little pricey, the food is quite good. We will definitely come back.
author: Lily L.

description:
I was taken here by my local work colleagues (I'm based in NYC). We were treated cheerily by the owner. I asked her the meaning of the name, and she said that she and the chef had 2 daughters, and debated between having a 3rd kid (aiming for a son) or open a restaurant... The menu is an eclectic mix of ethnic foods. Being a Korean, I was curious who made the Kimchee and how they learned it. The chef explained that he learned it himself by reading about it. Rather than shying away from being questioned about it, he sent a bowl of his plain kimchee (which is used as an accent on the menu for various dishes) to let us sample it and give feedback. Talk about someone who is open and confident. The kimchee was excellent, if a little under-fermented.

Anyway we greatly enjoyed ourselves--the staff did a nice job of helping us pick out fun things on the menu (all super delicious--I especially liked the octopus) and also were excellent with the wine. We had such a great time! Can't recommend highly enough.
author: Chris M.

description:
tl;dr delicious food. great wine selection and shockingly not a bazillion dollar signs. Rare and welcome!

We were searching for an affordable date night restaurant and found this new gem from the former chef of Marlowe. Upon walking in for our reservation, it turned out our table wasn't quite ready so the friendly host walked us over to the bar, and as soon as a seat opened up there, made sure we got to score it. Very thoughtful especially since we were only there for a moment before the table opened up. Bartender was super friendly and gave great wine recommendations (beer and wine only FYI).

Our waiter was also top notch and passed our fav waiter test when asked whether we ordered too much or too little. We love it when a waiter prevents us from over ordering because we have very big eyes. Kudos for honesty! 

For food, the Tuna and Uni tostada are scrumptious as everyone here seems to agree. The Roasted Hen of the Woods Mushrooms are delightfully flavorful. We took our waiter up on the Poached Chicken with Crispy Skin recommendation and were not disappointed. We shared the Black Cod which was tasty, but the Kimchi Romesco is what really made it. I will definitely return to try the Chicken Liver Mousse Toasts, Hamachi with pineapple-coconut water and Chicharrons!

Also, if you eat the beefs, which I do not, they say the burger is delicious!
author: Nikki M.

description:
We just had a pretty terrible experience here: made a reservation, arrived only to be told that our table was not close to being ready. The host was not able to give us an estimate for the wait time (we were told "there is one table before you and they have been waiting 30 minutes already") and was pretty unapologetic. It doesn't seem like they have any concept of what honoring a reservation means. Needless to say, we had booked a $20/hour babysitter so we left and had a lovely meal elsewhere.

The reason I gave them 2 stars and not 1 is that we had had a pretty good (albeit overpriced) brunch experience there before.
author: Sarah P.

description:
Hands down my new favorite spot in SF. Good for all occasions... love Kyle at the Bar. Hospitality is on point and the food is INSANE  

(Been open for three weeks and I've been here at least 5 times ! )
author: Emily C.

description:
Visited this place right when they opened in October '17 and it was great. Came back 5 months later and it's even better. 

The burger: get it. Hands down the best I've ever had

Chicken liver: they've perfected this to a level I didn't think was possible

Almond cake: I'm not a sweets person but this won me over.

South city cider: Again, not a cider guy but this was epic!

Cannot wait for my next visit!!
author: Daniel S.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood. We were walkins on a Saturday night and were very happy to get a table. Modern, cozy atmosphere, a bit loud and hot inside, asked them to open the door. 

The tostadas: yum! But it's a one bite kinda dish so just expect them to be small.

Ted Brussels sprouts another great winter dish with all the flavors, crunch and brightness.

The mushrooms were a bit bland, not a favorite.

The lamb was scrumptious, rich, falling off the bone, classically paired, and quite large so we shared.

Wine list was great, beers could use more variety.

All and all a great experience and food, service was also very good and attentive, lots of new places falter.  Looking forward to coming back.
author: Inga W.

description:
Nice new place with really good service and an interesting food menu; and the pricing is fair if not inexpensive.

Brussels sprouts panzanela with baby beets, goat cheese and warmed torn bread was nice.  The beets were more abundant than the sprouts as served to me; but that was alright as I love beets.  The goat cheese lent a bit of a sour taste to the salad; this isn't a complaint but rather a comment, as my next course also veered to the sour end of the taste spectrum.

Braised lamb shank with polenta and goat cheese was fall-off-the-bone tender.  The polenta was nicely prepared but again there was that somewhat bitter cheese.  As I ate it occurred to me that perhaps some poached prunes or slices of apple would have improved or balanced this plate.

But my comments only reflect my personal taste and overall this place is a winner.
author: David D.

description:
I was a bit skeptical of this place when I saw many 5 star reviews from reviews with less than a dozen written reviews but in the end I was happily impressed with this spot.

A friend and I stopped in here yesterday after this place had come up on my Yelp radar. We stopped in around 5:30 and it was a bit empty but it was packed by the time we left.

We were seated at a convenient spot in the middle of the restaurant which I was pleased with (I hate it when when I'm seated in a dark corner when I don't have a reservation).

We ordered the following:

Chicharron
Brussel Sprouts
Chicken Mouse Toast
Bone Marrow
Burger

Everything was made with care and we polished off every dish. Surprisingly I liked the chicharron because it included some big pieces of tasty pork - the skin was kind of a secondary part.

Anyway, the hype is deserved and you should hit this place up before word gets out!
author: Art O.

description:
Made a reservation online for four at 7:45 on a Monday. We arrived and our table was ready for us. Good thing we had a reservation because the place was packed!

We began by each ordering a glass of wine (no liquor license, so just wine and beer). Next, we each began the meal with a deviled egg. These were a spectacular way to get the salivary glands working! We all were excited for what was to come next. From the Small Plates, the four of us shared the curried octopus, Hen of the Woods mushrooms, and poached chicken with fried skin. 

The texture of the octopus was smooth, soft, and tender--flavor heavily dominated by coconut milk and curry. 

Hen of the Woods mushrooms were earthy and roasty. 

Poached Chicken with Fried Skin was a variety of textures: soft poached chicken; crispy skin; multiple types of rice. Flavors were bright ginger and soy--reminiscent of sushi.

For the mains we opted for the Skirt Steak and Petrale Sole. 

The Sole was crispy and browned on the exterior but was tender and flaked apart when cut. The accompanying creamy artichoke sauce was my highlight of the night. Snow peas added crisp & crunchy texture to the soft dish.

Skirt Steak: crushed rainbow baby potatoes were crispy and were buddied up next to asparagus situated beneath the rare steak medallions which were draped with uni butter. This was an earthy, rich, and satiating dish. 

The finale was two desserts: the dark chocolate chip cookies (2) and the Muscato sabayon with berry compote. The cookies came out warm, crisp on the outside and gooey on the inside. The sabayon was light, not too sweet and paired well with the sweet and tart berry compote. The whole berries in the compote exploded with fruitiness while swimming amidst the creamy, foamy, richness of the sabayon.

What a meal! What an experience. Service was nice but over-extended. The servers were great at silent service--not interrupting conversation while still progressing the meal.
author: Daniel E.

description:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Sagan

Hard to park: however, good food and service.
author: Stephen S.

description:
I was bummed with Son's Addition.  

We sat at the bar.  The bartender was friendly, but not service oriented.  We ordered the tuna and uni tostada.  The smallest tostada ever for $11 for two.  What a joke!  The flavor profile was a whirlwind of lost in too many components.  This dish tasted more like a guacamole chip.  The uni was non-existent in presence and flavor.  The uni and the tuna was not showcased whatsoever.   To make matters worse, they were the size of a dollar coin or a Tostadita.  Disappointed.

Furthermore, our hanger steak took forever!  Every table that came in after us, received their entrees.  We watched us the owner scuttled about the restaurant running the plates and checking in with the guests.  She did not check in with us which was a big FAIL with dining experience.  Finally, the bartender apologized that the kitchen was running behind.

They apologized via deviled eggs on the house and at the end of our meal with two warm chocolate chip cookies. 

We left Son's Addition with a bad taste in our mouth.  Too pricey, for a menu that is trying too hard.  Service was amuck.  Sad to say, I will not be returning.
author: Shellie K.

description:
Just bleh.  Food was hardly seasoned at all very bland.  We had the seasonal scramble and it was disappointing.   Also had the avocado toast, it needed more avocado was mostly the greens.  

I won't be back.
author: Graham T.

description: This place is a must do! The flavors are complex and perfectly paired. You'll have a "oh wow" moment after one deviled egg and will quickly order a second. The hamachi was my favorite! It has a small kick that was perfect for someone that isn't big on spice. We ended the dinner with a few desserts - the chocolate chip cookies with a touch of seas salt was melt in your mouth delicious!
author: Billie J.

description:
GREAT, I recommend for cosy dinner!

- Food 4*: Everything was very good, pretty eclectic tastes, definitely recommend the Heirloom Tomatoes, I'd go back just for those!
- Dessert 3*: Really really good Sabayon, my wife loved it, fresh yet soft. But the cookies were pretty disappointing, couldn't taste the DARK chocolate that much, and salt was a gimmick, just a bit on a corner...
- Drink 3*: My wife liked her French sparkling wine, but my Boon Danny wine was good/surprising at the first sip only, then it felt kinda taste less. Both too expensive ($15 and $14) for what it was.
- Place 4*: Very cute and cozy restaurant, not too fancy #bullshit, perfect for a casual date night. Not too noisy either, but the long row of tables in the middle were a bit too close to each other.
- Service 5*: Really nice and professional people, definitely bring this restaurant to higher standards. The place was fairly packed, but all the food came to us so fast, almost too fast.
- Price 4*: Total was $90 (1.5 drink, 1 appetizer, 2 small plates and 1 dessert) each. Not cheap nor crazy expensive. With better wines and dessert that would be a no brainer. Def worth the service though.
author: Clement P.

description: The service was warm, friendly and welcoming. It felt like I was in a well loved neighborhood restaurant. I loved my dining experience here. The deviled egg was an explosion of flavors with layers of salt and spice that kept rolling. I had to stop myself from ordering another round. The panzenella salad with heirloom tomatoes was my favorite of the night. Wines list is great with several affordable options. We went a bit early, about 7pm on a Friday and it wasn't crowded, but it definitely started to buzz by 8pm. This place had a great mix of patrons. It felt on trend, but not trendy. Take a date here.
author: Richard F.

description:
This is my 7th time here as I live nearby and after 1 year that they've been open.  I have eaten ne're everything on the menu, s0:

1.  My favorite local place was the Local eatery which, unfortunately closed.  So I was thrilled a place like this opened.

2.  This is a neighborhood place that is budget and ambiance friendly.  If your a "foodie", I'd make a reservation 3 weeks+ out and wait to get in somewhere else.  If you are a simple person who wants a diverse neighborhood with diverse food choices and be able to walk in and get a table, then, this is for you.  


3. The food is very good.  Is it the best I've ever ha in my life?  no.  Do I leave feeling that I ate well, was able to get in fairly quickly, and not break the bank- YES.

4. Staff and owners are super friendly and happy to be in this neighborhood.

5. I agree it's a bit loud but there's nothing to be done for that.  If you want quiet/romantic, etc. I'd look elsewhere.

6. Pate toasts; octopus, shaved summer squash, beef tartar, pork chop.

So, highly advise this for the people out there looking for a scrumptious yet budget friendly, local place.
author: Lucia C.

description: True score: 3.5. Just went here for a quick bite on Saturday night. Was able to walk in around 8:45 and got a seat for 2. The staff was very friendly and helpful. We opted to sit at the bar. I order a glass of the cab-sav and my husband had an IPA. My cab-sav was only $11 (which is on the less-expensive end I thought) but the glass of wine was warmer than it should've been and too many tannins. The IPA was fruity which I loved but wasn't the hubbys favorite. We ordered the kimchi eggs which were tasty but it's strange they sell half of an egg individually. We also ordered the burger to split which I thought was pretty good but by no means great or super flavorful. I prefer the burgers we have had at Marlowe. I would consider coming back but wouldn't be on the top of my list. One of the highlights....Humphry Slocombe is steps away!
author: Natasha B.

description:
Oh, wow - what a great addition to the Mission! Highlights: 
- Tuna and uni tostadas. These are light on the uni (if you're not a big fan) and are wonderfully flavored. You get two, bite-sized tostadas per order, and while I would recommend ordering more because they're so delicious, I won't because you'll want to try a bunch of other small plates!
